Review The action mechanisms and structures designs of F-containing functional materials for high performance oxygen electrocatalysis Gang Wang a b Shuwei Jia a Hongjing Gao a Yewen Shui a Jie Fan a Yixia Zhao a Lei Li a Weimin Kang a ⁎ Nanping Deng a b ⁎ Bowen Cheng a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes School of Textile Science and Engineering Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China b School of Material Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China School of Material Science and Engineering Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China School of Material Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The review summarizes the fluorine-containing electrocatalysts from the perspectives of material preparations, mechanisms of action and geometry. The reasons for the improved oxygen electrocatalysis (OER and ORR) performance are deeply analyzed and the future development directions for fluorine-containing oxygen electrocatalysts also are proposed. Non-renewable fossil fuels have led to serious problems such as global warming, environmental pollution, etc. Oxygen electrocatalysis including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays a central role in clean energy conversion, enabling a number of sustainable processes for future air battery technologies. Fluorine, as the most electronegative element (4.0) not only can induce more efficient regulation for the electronic structure, but also can bring more abundant defects and other novel effects in materials selection and preparation for favorable catalysis with respect to the other non-metal elements. However, an individual and comprehensive overview of fluorine-containing functional materials for oxygen electrocatalysis field is still blank. Therefore, it is very meaningful to review the recent progresses of fluorine-containing oxygen electrocatalysts. In this review, we first systematically summarize the controllable preparation methods and their possible development directions based on fluorine-containing materials from four preparation methods. Due to the strong electron-withdrawing properties of fluorine, its control of the electronic structure can effectively enhance the oxygen electrocatalytic activity of the materials. In addition, the catalytic enhancement effect of fluorine on carbon-based materials also includes the prevent oxidation and the layer peeling, and realizes the precise atomic control. And the catalytic improvement mechanism of fluorine containing metal-based compounds also includes the hydration of metal site, the crystal transformation, and the oxygen vacancy induction. Then, based on their various dimensions (0D–3D), we also have summarized the advantages of different morphologies on oxygen electrocatalytic performances. Finally, the prospects and possible future researching direction of F-containing oxygen electrocatalysts are presented (e.g., novel pathways, advanced methods for measurement and simulation, field assistance and multi-functions). The review is considered valuable and helpful in exploring the novel designs and mechanism analyses of advanced fluorine-containing electrocatalysts. Keywords Fluorine-containing functional materials Action mechanisms and structure designs Density functional theory Oxygen evolution reaction Oxygen reduction reaction 1 Introduction Recent findings and researches pointed out that the annual global energy consumption could over 4 × 1020 J, and non-renewable fossil fuels including coal, oil, and natural gas, lead to serious problems such as global warming, environmental pollution, etc. [1,2]. Electrocatalysis plays a significant role in clean energy conversion, enabling a number of sustainable routes for future technologies [3]. In this regard, fuel cells and metal-air batteries are increasingly favored due to their high energy density and environmental benignity [4]. Oxygen electrocatalysts play an irreplaceable role in these energy conversion devices [5]. However, their commonly required noble metal catalysts (e.g., Pt/C for ORR and Ir/C for OER) are limited in application due to high cost and scarce reserves [6]. Because of cost, activity, and durability issues surrounding the noble-metal-based electrocatalysts, considerable efforts have been directed at designing and synthesizing novel catalysts to reduce the amount of noble-metals [7]. Hence, various alternatives are researched and reported which mainly included carbon ball [8], carbon nanofibers [9], graphene [10], frame material derived carbon [11], alloys [12], metal-oxides [13], metal-oxyhydroxides [14], metal-hydroxylates [15], MXexes [16], perovskites [17] and so on. Interestingly, fluorine element, as the most electronegative element (4.0) may not only induce much more efficient regulation for the electronic structure, but also can bring more abundant defects and other novel effects in materials selection and preparation for favorable catalysis with respect to the other non-metal elements [18,19]. At present, fluorine-doped materials have been widely applied in catalyst immobilization [20], carbon fixation [21], methanol oxidation reaction [22], urea oxidation reaction [23], hydrogen evolution reaction [24], oxygen evolution reaction [25] and oxygen reduction reaction [26]. Due to the indispensable role of oxygen catalyzed reactions (ORR and OER) in the field of energy conversion and the unique enhancement of fluorine to oxygen catalysts, recent many advances in F-containing oxygen electrocatalysts should be reviewed. The ORR (Eqs. (1)–(4)) and OER (Eqs. (5)–(8)) process mainly consists of the following reaction steps (take the alkaline electrolyte as an instance) [27–29]. (1) O 2 g + H 2 O l + e - + ∗ → O O H ∗ + O H - (2) O O H ∗ + e - → O ∗ + O H - (3) O ∗ + H 2 O l + e - → O H ∗ + O H - (4) O H ∗ + e - → ∗ + O H - (5) ∗ + O H - → O H ∗ + e - (6) O H ∗ + O H - → O ∗ + H 2 O l + e - (7) O ∗ + O H - → O O H ∗ + e - (8) O O H ∗ + O H - → O 2 g + H 2 O l + e - + ∗ where * stands for an active site on the catalytic surface, (l) and (g) refer to liquid and gas phases, respectively. OER is considered to be the reverse reaction of the above process [28,29]. The classic reaction process theoretical models are widely used for the mechanism exploration in oxygen electrocatalysis. A large number of studies for F-containing materials in oxygen electrocatalysis have been reported, an individual and comprehensive overview of fluorine-containing functional materials for oxygen electrocatalysis field is still blank. In this review as presented in Fig. 1 , we systematically summarize controllable preparation methods based on fluorine-containing materials. The effects of materials by fluorine element or fluorine doping process were classified, and the corresponding mechanisms and expected effects were summarized. Then we also summarize the affect for improving the oxygen electrocatalytic performances of fluorine-containing materials based on their various dimensions (0D–3D). More importantly, the prospects and possible future research directions of F-containing oxygen electrocatalysts are presented. This review is considered valuable and helpful in exploring the novel design and mechanism analysis of advanced fluorine-containing electrocatalysts. 2 Fabrication of F-containing functional materials for oxygen electrocatalysts The high electronegativity (4.0) of fluorine leads to the excellent properties of fluorine-containing oxygen catalysts such as enhanced conductivity, increased surface area, low reaction barrier and raised hydrophilicity. As shown in Fig. 2 , the preparation process of fluorine-containing oxygen catalysts can be mainly divided into adsorption, thermal doping, co-crystallization, self-assembly, and so on. Different preparation processes have their own advantages and disadvantages. 2.1 Adsorption Fluorine can be enriched into the material by adsorption. Its minimalist operating characteristics make it promising for large-scale industrialization. As a carbonization precursor, ion exchange resin can adsorb metal–fluorine complex ions, and then can be used to obtain functional materials with high fluorine content. Yue and co-workers found that Ta sites would distribute more positive charge from the TaO2F crystal when compared with the TaO2 [30]. F in metal compounds might cause strong electron absorption effect to induce band gap reduction for assisting fast electron transfer for excellent OER activity. For metal compounds, F anion could be adsorbed in the metal-cation gel. Kim et al. conducted F anion doping of SnO2 with at the atomic level by using a sol–gel method to resolve the low-conductivity issue [31]. After achieving an observable band gap expansion because of the F-doping, the F-doped SnO2 showed higher conductivity when compared with pure SnO2, which is responsible for a significant decrement in the electrochemical charge transfer resistance. Generally speaking, the adsorption method has the advantages of simple operation, large output and easy purification and cleaning. However, functional materials with large ion adsorption capacity usually have poor electrical conductivity to be directly applied to electrocatalytic conversion processes. On the one hand, carbon material precursor is used for adsorption and then calcination to obtain a highly conductive fluorine-containing catalyst. On the other hand, adding highly conductive materials for the fluorine-embedded metal compounds can also facilitate the electrocatalytic conversion process. 2.2 Thermal doping The thermal doping generally means that fluorine-containing fluids (solutions and atmospheres) infiltrate fluorine into the material through molecular thermal motion. Thermal doping is one of the most important preparation methods for fluorine-containing oxygen catalysts. The method has the advantages of simple operation, wide applicability and easy control of fluorine doping amount. A lot of studies have used NH4F as the fluorine source. In addition, due to the good molding properties of fluorine-containing polymers (e.g., PTFE, PVDF and so on [32]), its pyrolysis process can also be applied to the fluorine modification of materials. For carbon materials, thermal doping can be etched and fluorine infiltrated, thereby obtaining a rougher carbon surface and fluorine-containing catalytic active sites to enhance the electrocatalytic conversion performance. In addition, thermal doping of fluorine on metal materials also can generate metal fluorides while maintaining the conductive properties. The generated metal fluoride will be hydrolyzed to metal oxyhydroxide with high oxygen evolution activity in alkaline system to enhance the electrocatalytic conversion performance of the functional materials. For the metal materials, Xu et al. firstly introduced F into the NiFe structure via a rapid (∼1 min) treatment at 250 °C in molten hydrated ammonium fluoride. And then the electrochemical activation reconstructs the fluorinated NiFe metal nanoparticle for the enhanced oxygen evolution catalysis. For carbon materials, Leng et al. fabricated fluorinated iron and cobalt bimetallic supported on catalyst carbon nanofibers by using PVDF as the fluorine source [33]. Compared with the monometallic fluorides, the interaction of CoF2 and FeF2 resulted in faster faradaic redox reactions and higher electrical conductivity, which improved the ORR electrocatalysis performances. The fluorination strongly increased the charge density of the bimetallic catalyst, which optimized the charge distribution of the active site and improved the ORR activity. However, the fluorination of carbon generally requires long time to wait for the fluorination to complete. As a novel developed method, deflagration has attracted much attention due to its extremely fast preparation speed (less than a few seconds). The method uses gaseous precursors to achieve rapid carbonization and fluorine doping. Liu et al. developed a NaN3/C5F5N deflagration method to synthesize high N/F co-doped carbon hollow nanospheres (N/F-HC) with a high graphitization degree [8]. The optimized N/F-HC catalyst exhibited superior ORR performance with long-term stability when compared to a commercial Pt/C electrocatalyst in an alkaline medium. 2.3 Co-crystallization The co-crystallization means that the metal compounds are crystallizing with fluorine, which process leads to the formation of oxygen vacancies [34], a large number of active sites [35], the change of the band structure [36] and so on. The main application fields are the metal foam modification [37], the hydrothermal synthesis [38] and the perovskite structural adjustment [39]. For the metal foam modification [37], self-supporting electrocatalysts can be prepared using metal foam as the nickel source and framework. By using NH4F, Patil et al. prepared F-doped Ni(OH)2 nanosheets on the surface of nickel foam. The doping of fluorine could lead to the generation of oxygen vacancies and an increase in the density of states near the Fermi level, improving the charge migration and substance transformation for the electrocatalytic reactions. For hydrothermal synthesis, Xie and co-workers prepared the fluorine anions doped hematite nanocrystals to achieve excellent OER performance and light absorption [38]. They added NH4F to achieve fluorine doping during the hydrothermal synthesis of Fe2O3 nanocrystals from iron acetylacetonate. Upon F-doping, the band structure of hematite could be effectively regulated, leading to the generation of defect levels between the band gaps. In general, the crystal structure of fluorination by the co-crystallization remains unchanged. In particular, fluorine can sometimes transform the crystal structure of perovskite. It is worth noting that Wang et al. found that fluoride ions can replace specific atoms at specific positions to transform the crystal structure of perovskites and achieve excellent OER performance [39]. And F-dopants could function effectively in transforming the hexagonal structure of oxides into a cubic one. The transformation of crystals greatly improved the electrocatalytic conversion efficiency. 2.4 Self-assembly The self-assembly process of the frame materials (e.g., COFs [11] and MOFs [40]) can add fluorine to materials by using fluorine-containing ligands. The high catalytic conversion efficiency catalysts can be formed by precisely coordinating materials. The self-assembly method has great flexibility and can precisely design the local chemical environment. After being carbonized at high temperature, an excellent conductive carbon material can be formed with a large number of fluorine-enhanced catalytic active sites. The effective co-doping of N and F in highly-porous carbon materials still is very challenging. Sun et al. introduced a one-step carbonization strategy based on a well-designed covalent organic framework (COF) to achieve a highly functional catalyst for the air cathode. The F doping with graphitic and pyridinic N triggers active paramagnetic centers to especially give the lowest free energy barrier for both ORR/OER. For the MOFs, Ma and co-workers prepared a novel N, O, S and F co-doping vesicular carbon by pyrolyzing a Na-based MOF [40]. The introduction of F in the carbon matrix with suitable content could regulate the adsorption of intermediates, which was favorable to its decomposition in charge process. In conclusion, the fabrication of F-containing catalysts is an important researching direction. Most of the existing work has focused on thermal-doping of fluorine into the shaped materials or its inclusion in the carbonization process. And other fabrication methods also have their own unique advantages. Therefore, in order to achieve high fluorine content, it is a great challenge to select the suitable fluorination method for different target materials. The traditional fluorination process has many disadvantages such as slow preparation speed, low fluorine content, and so on. It is very meaningful to develop and innovate the fluorination process for these aspects. 3 ORR/OER mechanisms of performance improvement Fluorine provides a general strategy to produce highly efficient electrocatalysts with reasonable porosity, good electrical conductivity, and outstanding chemical stability for reliable electrochemical energy conversion devices. As shown in Fig. 3 , it is no doubt that fluorine in these materials can optimize the electronic structure. Finally, the reasonable electronic structure could effectively improve the oxygen catalytic activity. For carbon materials, the following mechanisms can further improve the ORR performance. (a) The fluorine enrichment at the edge of the carbon material also can prevent the corrosion of the carbon materials and improve the ORR catalytic stability by reducing the binding energy between oxygen and the F-substituted edge of materials. (b) The fluorine in the graphite material can decrease the interlayer binding energy to enlarge the layer distance, which greatly increase the specific surface area and exposes enough active sites for ORR catalysis. (c) The fluorine in carbon materials can produce synergistic effects with other heteroatoms to enhance ORR performance. For metal and metal compounds, the following mechanisms can further improve the OER performance. (a) The fluorine in the metal compound can be dissolved out in the reaction system, which can generate a porous structure and can be replaced by water and oxygen at the edge to generate a highly OER active oxyhydroxides. (b) The doping of fluorine in metal compounds can transform the crystal structure, thereby enhancing the OER intrinsic catalytic activity. (c) The F-doping in metal oxides can induce oxygen vacancies, which synergistically adjust the internal charge structure and enhance the electrical conductivity for improving the OER performances. These modification methods can give materials many properties to enhance the electrocatalytic performances (e.g., increased stability, more exposed active sites, optimized atomic arrangement, enhanced conductivity, improved hydrophilic, raised catalytic activity, and so on). 3.1 Oxygen reduction reaction The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is the slowest kinetic process in fuel cells, which restricts the wide application of fuel cells. Fluorination of the materials can optimize the electronic structure for effectively enhancing oxygen reduction electrocatalytic performances. Notably, the marginal substitution of fluorine prevents oxidation for significantly stabling structures. And fluorine also increases interlayer spacing to make layer peeled for exposing more active sites. Meanwhile, the addition of fluorine may cause atomic rearrangement to achieve precisely atomic control as shown in Fig. 4 . The number and activity of electrocatalytic sites, electron transport ability, the stability of carbon skeleton and the control ability of local chemical environment related to ORR performance of F-containing materials can be effectively enhanced due to the mentioned above mechanisms. 3.1.1 Reasonable electronic adjustment for ORR For the first time, Xing’s group found that the doping of fluorine alone on inexpensive carbon blacks can induce superior high ORR electrocatalytic performance by the electronic adjustment of F–C bonds [41]. For the F-doped carbon materials, the following active C–F species were found: ionic C–F, covalent C–F and semi-ionic C–F [42,43]. Furthermore, Chang et al. designed and prepared three conformations of stable fluorine-doped graphene, all the associated single site’s activities were given on the activity volcano on Fig. 5 (a) and the total activities of F-doped on armchair edge (A–F), bulk (B–F) and zigzag edge (Z–F) on Fig. 5(b). While the models of the three patterns were given on Fig. 5(c), the F at edges of the graphene structure could enhance the ORR performance [44]. As shown in Fig. 5(d), the fluorine-doped graphene nanoribbons (F-GNR) have a lower band gap energy (0.032 eV) than the GNR (0.646 eV) and the higher abundance of electrons of fluorine than hydrogen might contribute to reducing the electronic band gap by promoting electron transfer to improve the electronic conductivity [45]. Moreover, the fluorine on graphene may moderately activate the O2 molecule and promote the subsequent ORR through a novel and more efficient 4e associative pathway (Fig. 5e) [46]. In addition, the incorporation of fluorine into the pyridinic-N configuration can significantly improve the charge and spin densities of the adjacent carbon atoms to enhance the activity of ORR [47]. The highest electronegativity of fluorine also helps to attract electrons from metal atoms, which optimizes the charge distribution of the active site for reducing the reaction activation energy and improves the ORR activity. Leng and co-workers introduced fluoride into the electrospinning precursor for the further formation of metal-F bonds to modulate the electronic structure around the active sites for enhancing ORR activity [33]. In addition, fluorine is useful for tuning the electronic structure of the metal-nitrogen-carbon active site to further enhance the ORR performance. Tao et al. have certified that electron withdrawing F element could weaken the intermediates adsorption of the OH* on the FeN4 active sites, which led to the strong catalytic activity for ORR [48]. 3.1.2 Prevent oxidation for stable structure It is particularly notable that sometimes fluorine doping can effectively inhibit the adsorption of oxygen by carbon atoms to prevent the carbon matrix from reacting with oxygen, thus further improving the stability of the materials [49,50]. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), the H2O and O are weakly bonded with the F-GNR when compared to the GNR, indicating that the prepared GNR can significantly enhance the carbon corrosion resistance by fluorine doping. The binding energy (BE) between O and the F-GNR is a positive value, thus the F-GNR is unfavorable to the combining with O for inhibiting the carbon corrosion in ORR [45]. In addition, the interaction between Pt and fluorinated-carbon allows a strong charge transfer from Pt to the carbon support, which can improve the catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst towards ORR combing their merits [51,52]. 3.1.3 Layer peeling based on increase interlayer spacing Due to volume repulsion, fluorine atoms in graphite will increase the interlayer spacing to form numerous slit-shaped pores and even exfoliate into graphene. Sahu and co-workers found that the presence of nitrogen enhanced this effect (Fig. 6b and c), and it is proven by DFT simulations ( Fig. 6d and e) [53]. Heating enhances the vibrations of fluorine atoms between graphene layers for peeling graphite fluoride to graphene fluoride in H2SO4 solution [54]. Due to the penetration of fluorine-containing vapors, the edges of graphene can be roughened to provide more active sites for enhancing ORR performance [10]. Furthermore, Wang et al. treated γ-graphene with CF4 plasma for partially curl structure to enhance the diffusion rate of O2 and increase more active sites for ORR. Based on the addition of F and the designed porous structure, the composite materials presented excellent ORR performance [55]. 3.1.4 Precise atomic control The addition of fluorine can precisely adjust the microenvironment of other heteroatoms. Sometimes, introduction of F atoms into the carbon matrix can break the graphitic bonds and then cause a high ratio of pyrrolic-N and pyridinic-N [56]. In addition, fluorine can optimize the electronic structure of the FeN4 active center and decrease the adsorption energy of ORR intermediates [48]. Furthermore, the latest experimental analyses and theoretical calculations all reveal that F coordination can weaken the CN bonds and drive the N atoms to the surface of Pd clusters, implying that the F regulates the local coordination environment (LCE) without blocking access to the active sites, rather than covering and affecting Pd directly (Fig. 6f) [26]. The surface PdN bonds inhibit the migration and agglomeration of Pd to enhance the catalytic activity for ORR [26]. 3.2 Oxygen evolution reaction In second metal-air batteries and water splitting, the slow oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process limits the electrochemical performance as shown in Fig. 7 . The reasonable electronic structure optimization of fluorine in materials can enhance the oxygen evolution reaction electrocatalytic performances. Notably, the dissolution of fluorine and the metal hydrated products in alkaline solution have raised catalytic activity and improved hydrophilic. And the crystal transformations involving fluorine also could design and prepare novel materials for enhanced conductivity and raised catalytic activity. Meanwhile, the F-doping can induce oxygen vacancies to improve the electrocatalytic activity and electronic conductivity. Due to these mechanisms or their combination, the catalytic activity, electron transport ability and hydrophilicity can be enhanced to improve OER performances. 3.2.1 Reasonable electronic adjustment for OER The charge regulation effect of fluorine atoms in modified carbon materials can also improve the OER performance. Numerous studies have suggested that fluorine is predominantly attached to carbon materials as covalent (C–F) and semi-ionic (C–F) moieties, and the carbon atoms which covalently attached to fluorine can provide more active sites for OER [57]. Further, it was confirmed that the higher charge density distributed on carbon around the heteroatoms can offer high electrocatalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), the carbon atomic charge of the graphite-N with F on graphene (gN, F–G) is the highest (0.478 e), which is in favor for the optimizing transition state energy to enhance the OER activity [58]. In some cases, the F doping with graphitic and pyridinic N triggers can activate paramagnetic centers, which could greatly reduce the activation energy for improving the OER performance [11]. It cannot be ignored that F-doping would replace the original anion sites in metal compounds by fluorine atoms, which directly affect the charge state of surrounding atoms, thus reducing the reaction barrier for OER. For instance, Chen and co-workers verified that F could result in a more optimized adsorption energy between the Fe sites and OH−, and facilitate Fe4+ formation based on more positive charge densities of the Fe sites to improve OER activity [36]. In addition, fluorine doping sites in metal compounds are beneficial for increasing the electron density near Fermi level, thereby enhancing electron transport capability [64]. As shown in Fig. 8(b), Hao and co-workers found that the incorporation of fluorine led to a higher electron density at the Fermi level of Ni3S2, which can increase the electron cloud density around the Fermi level, resulting in the improved electrical conductivity and the enhanced OER performance [59]. In addition, F-doping can be used as an n-type additive to enhance the photoelectron activity to enhance the photo-electrocatalytic OER performance. For example, the fluorine in the CoOOH/FeOOH/F-Fe2O3 photoanode material as an n-type (donor) dopant could increase the electron density of α-Fe2O3 to improve the electronic conductivity and decrease the charge-transfer resistance to enhance photo-electrocatalytic activities for OER [65]. 3.2.2 F-dissolution and metal hydration The dissolution of fluoride ions to alkaline solution would cause a charge imbalance at the metal ion sites and a loose structure. The charge imbalance at metal sites would attract and combine the surrounding hydroxide ions and oxygen molecules to form a high electrocatalytic active surface by oxyhydroxides or hydroxides. The oxyhydroxide and hydroxide are widely recognized as a high catalysis activity sites and powerful hydrophilicity component. The in situ formed synergy of the surface metal hydroxide/oxyhydroxide and the beneath F-doped transition metal compound could further improve the electrocatalytic activity. And the loose structure and hydrophilic properties are rather beneficial to enhance the desorption of oxygen and improve the OER performance. For instance, Zhou and co-workers converted the well-latticed NiMoO4@MNF to loosely structured F-NiMoO4@MNF (Fig. 8c) [60]. The emerged loose amorphous structure was conducive to the dynamic migration of F species and effective penetration of the electrolyte. And the exchange between F and hydroxide anions induces the formation of an active oxyhydroxide layer. The active oxyhydroxide layer also can optimize the electronic structure and absorption/desorption energy on the surface of F-NiMoO4@MNF for enhanced OER performance. 3.2.3 Crystal transformation The metal fluorides from the fluorination process form heterostructures with the original metal compounds. The heterostructure materials have a large number of defects with electrocatalytic activity for OER. For example, the fluorination process in the iron oxides porous nanofilm leads to the numerous dislocations and distortions marked with “T” as shown in Fig. 8(d and e), which can strongly improve the OER performance [61]. Furthermore, the addition of fluorine could effectively transform the crystal type in the process of synthesizing metal hydroxides based on the hydrothermal reaction. Wang et al. designed and prepared a stable cubic perovskite SrCoO2.85F0.15 by anion F-doping instead of traditional A and/or B site doping (Fig. 8f) (traditional perovskite is the material with a crystal structure following the formula ABX3, when A and B are metal cations, and the C is anion), which demonstrated enhanced conductivity and excellent OER activity superior to hexagonal compound H-Sr2Co2O5 [39]. Furthermore, in the fluorination process, the NiFe nanoparticles can be converted into ultra-thin NiFeO x F y nanosheets as shown in Fig. 8(g) [62]. The intermediate product also can transform into the desired defective NiFeO x H y shell after the application of electrochemical activation, which could substantially improve surface wettability and enhance gas-bubble-releasing behavior for effective OER. 3.2.4 Oxygen vacancy induction The F doping into metal oxide can effectively modulate the electronic structure. In some cases, abundant oxygen vacancies would be induced and formed. More importantly, the obtained oxygen vacancies will lead to the offset and polarization of surrounding atoms, which can easily form electrocatalytic active sites and enhance electron conductivity. Xie and coworkers introduced fluorine into CoMoO4 to decrease the energy gap from 1.98 to 1.35 eV for improving the electrical conductivity to accelerate OER [18]. In addition, F doping in the YRuO also could provide oxygen vacancies, reducing the distance between the d-band center of transition metals and the p-band center of oxygen (Fig. 8h), which made the transport of electrons easier [63]. It is worth mentioning that the used DFT calculations and kinetic analysis of F-Co3O4− x also disclosed that F-doping and O-vacancy could synergistically reduce the energy barriers of water dissociation steps for more efficient OER process [34]. In conclusion, the enhancement mechanism of the catalyst with the strongest electronegativity of fluorine will definitely include the adjustment of the electronic structure, no matter it is a metal-based material or a carbon-based material. A reasonable electronic structure can effectively improve the electronic conductivity and reduce the activation energy. Besides that, for carbon materials, the enhancement mechanisms also include (i) edge fluorine substitution to enhance carbon matrix stability; (ii) fluorine etching of carbon materials to exfoliate the graphite layer; (iii) precise control of various atoms. Due to the wide variety of possible active sites in carbon materials, ensuring true active sites is challenging. Current researches generally use density functional theory to perform transition state simulations for finding possible active sites. However, few studies have characterized the catalytic process in situ through the transition state to verify the corresponding simulation results. Therefore, there is still a need to develop new in situ characterization approaches to understand their more fundamental mechanisms of action. For the F-containing metal based compounds, the unique enhancement mechanisms include the following: (i) the fluorine in the metal compound can be dissolved out in the reaction system and be replaced by water and oxygen at the edge to generate a highly active oxyhydroxide for OER; (ii) the doping of fluorine in metal compounds can transform the crystal structure, thereby enhancing the OER intrinsic catalytic activity; (iii) the F-doping in metal oxides can induce oxygen vacancies, which synergistically adjust the internal charge structure and enhance the electrical conductivity for improving the electrocatalytic performances. When compared with carbon materials, metal-based materials have strong advantages in catalytic OER. Generally speaking, the energy difference is comparatively small between general metal hydroxides and metal oxyhydroxides. Therefore, developing high-performance metal-based ORR catalysts is a great challenge. If a functional material with a large energy difference between oxyhydroxide and hydroxide can be developed, it is expected to prepare high-performance metal-based ORR catalysts, which would be a very interesting and important research direction. 4 Application of F-containing materials in oxygen catalysis It is widely recognized that different morphologies and structures have certain effects for oxygen electrocatalysis. The general way to classify morphologies and structures is to distinguish their dimensions of extension directions: (1) the 0-dimensional (0D) materials refer to substances that extend in the diameter direction such as particles and spheres; (2) the 1D materials are defined as substances with large aspect ratios such as fibers, tubes, wires, etc.; (3) the 2D materials generally involve some layered materials, which mainly are represented by graphene and metal oxyhydroxide nanosheet sites; (4) the 3D materials generally refer to framework materials such as metal foams and self-assembled organic coordination framework materials. All in all, various materials with different dimensions have their own advantages in oxygen electrocatalysis. 4.1 0D materials The 0D materials have received increasing attention due to their adjustable pore size distribution, designable shells, unique surface properties and ultra-high specific surface. Li et al. changed the electronic structure of Pt by the electron withdrawing effect of fluorine on carbon nanoparticles, which could enhance the electrocatalytic activity and electrochemical stability in ORR [51]. For reducing the Pt usage, various F-contained carbon electrocatalysts have been developed and applied for ORR. The maximum charge polarization in some porous carbon matrix by F-doping is beneficial for the preferential orientation of O2 molecules and the subsequent ORR. Due to this electronic charge adjustment, ionic C–F, semi-ionic C–F and covalent C–F are widely recognized to be acted as catalyst in ORR [42,43]. Xing’s group found the F-doping on 0D carbon materials could induce superior high ORR electrocatalytic performance which is competitive with Pt/C catalysts [41]. In addition, the synergistic effect of F and other heteroatoms such as Si, N and so on can further enhance the oxygen electrocatalytic performance of the prepared functional materials. Due to the change in energetic characteristics of silicon and fluorine, Abbas et al. found that due to the presence of the ionic and semi-ionic C–F bonds and silicon dopant on the surface of the carbon materials, the Si–C–F decorated porous carbons exhibited much better ORR electrocatalytic performance when compared to the unitary doped silicon or fluorine [66]. More importantly, F, N co-doped carbon electrocatalysts are more fully researched. Due to the N-enrichment effect by fluorine, Wang et al. and Shah et al. designed and reported F, N co-doped 0D carbon materials for enhancing the ORR performance (Fig. 9 a) [67,68]. Wang and co-workers synthesized F, N co-doped ordered mesoporous carbon (FN-OMC) by employing inexpensive resorcin as a carbon precursor and ammonium fluoride as a fluorine and nitrogen source [67]. Shah et al. established gas–liquid interfaces during pyrolysis by salt-assisted synthetic strategy to prepare mesoporous F, N-doped nanocarbons for ORR [68]. In addition, Zhang et al. also found that F-doping can enhance the catalytic activity of CN bond in F, N co-doped carbon and exhibits high ORR performance [47]. For increasing the preparation speed and heteroatom content in carbon materials, Liu et al. developed a NaN3/C5F5N deflagration method to synthesize carbon hollow nanospheres with the ultra-fast prepared speed (in seconds), well graphitization degree and large N/F doping content, which exhibited superior ORR performance with long-term stability as shown in Fig. 9(b) [8]. More importantly, the utilization rate of biomass also has attracted more and more attention due to wide source, low cost and little environmental pollution of biomass. Akula et al., Wu et al. and Wang et al. used various biomasses as a green carbon source to prepare N–F co-doping porous carbon [70–73]. The pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphical-N, C–F ionic and C–F semi-ionic active species in the biomass-based carbon materials are helpful for achieving the maximum polarization, realizing the charge redistribution and high spin densities for increasing the ORR activity. Tri-doped carbon materials of heteroatoms may further enhance the synergistic effect to induce charge redistribution for improving the electrocatalytic performance. Because the electronegativity of phosphorus (2.19) is lower than carbon, the P would become stronger active sites for ORR to a certain extent [74]. Due to the enhanced activity by P, Cui et al. designed and prepared the N, P, F-tridoped mesoporous carbons by pyrolyzing the homogeneous mixture of melamine and BmimPF6 for high electrocatalytic ORR activity [74]. The doped S species demonstrated the ability in inducing “electron spin” redistribution to play an important contribution in improving ORR activity. Lv et al. synthesized S, N, F tri-doped carbon as an efficient metal-free electrocatalyst for ORR [75]. The charge redistribution of carbon matrix was induced by the synergistic effect of heteroatoms to improve the ORR performance. In metal compounds, F-doping might cause strong electron absorption effect to assist electron transfer to generate more active sites for excellent ORR activity. Zhang et al. also demonstrated F co-doped Co/N/C electrocatalysts for ORR [76]. Based on the numerous defects of element coexistence, the F co-doped Co/N/C electrocatalysts exhibited an excellent electrocatalytic performance for ORR. The 0D material also exhibits excellent OER activity due to the adjustable pore size, unique surface properties especially the abundantly active crystal plane exposure of metal compounds. The electronic charge distribution analysis in the IrO2 nanoparticles by Kumta’s group indicated that the smaller ionic charge of fluorine in comparison with oxygen can play an important contribution to a decrease in energy barrier and hence the OER activity can be improved [77]. Through DFT simulation, Wang et al. found that those increased oxygen vacancies in the prepared Y2Ru2O7−δ nanoparticles could be attributed to causing the lattice oxygen evolution mechanism by strengthening the Ru-O co-valency, thus the OER catalytic activity of the Y2Ru2O7−δ nanoparticles was positively correlated with oxygen vacancies concentration [63]. In order to reduce the amount of noble metals, transition metal compounds exhibit strong cost advantages for OER. The F-doping of metal compounds leads to more defects, which may generate more active sites for significantly improving OER performance. Lemoine et al., Pei et al. and Han et al. prepared MnFeF4.6O0.2 nanoparticles, F-doped FeNi nanoparticles and nickel–cobalt fluoride oxides (NCFO) as OER electrocatalysts, respectively [78–80]. And the obtained electrocatalysts all can strongly improve the OER performance. In addition, F in metal compounds might cause strong electron absorption effect to induce band gap reduction to assist electron transfer for excellent OER activity. Yue and co-workers found that Ta sites would distribute more positive charge from the TaO2F crystal compared with the TaO2 to optimize the transition states of OER for improving the electrocatalytic activity for OER [30]. On this basis, metal-doping or double metal elements would cause changes in the charge distribution to introduce more catalytically active sites in F-doped metal compounds and metal fluorides. Xie et al., Lemoine et al. and Xue et al. respectively prepared V, F co-doped Co3O4, NiFe2F4.4O1.8 and NiF2·CoF2, which show excellent OER activity due to the electronic absorption [81–83]. The NiFe2F4.4O1.8 behaved the lowest over-potential due to the high intrinsic OER activity by Ni-Fe hydration products. By applying density functional theory (DFT) calculations, it is demonstrated that the cubic SrCoO3 parent oxide would deliver the highest OER activity [84]. But it is very difficult to prepare an ideal SrCoO3 perovskite cubic structure [85]. For lattice modulation, Wang et al. prepared a stable cubic perovskite SrCoO3-δ particles by anion F-doping instead of traditional A and/or B site doping (ABX3 is the default perovskite composition, A and B are cations while X is anion) [39]. The tested results demonstrated the enhanced conductivity and excellent OER activity can be realized and it was superior to hexagonal compound H-Sr2Co2O5 without F-doping. More importantly, bifunctional catalysts for both ORR and OER are of great significance. Zhu et al. also synthesized N, F co-doped carbon black and found that the fluorine could provide efficient active sites by itself due to the synergistic effects with N and produce more carbon defects for enhancing the OER and ORR performance [86]. Moreover, B atoms also can cause electron modulation to change the charge distribution to induced defects to facilitate the OER/ORR process. Zhang and co-workers synthesized B/N/F tri-doped carbon nanoparticles, which could exhibit superior ORR/OER activity due to the modulated electronic structure of the carbon atoms by means of heteroatom doping [87]. F not only can attract the electron of CoN4 active sites to enhance the ORR activity, but also can improve the hydration of Co-CoF2 to accelerate OER. Due to these effects, Zhu et al. prepared Co-CoF2 doped Co/N/C electrocatalysts for efficient OER/ORR (E 1/2 = 0.852 V, vs. RHE, 300 mV at 10 mA cm−2) [88]. Tables 1 and 2 summarize the ORR and OER properties of OD materials, respectively. It can be seen from Table 1 that the 0D F-doped carbon can effectively improve the E 1/2 to ∼0.82 V due to the electronic optimization. To further enhance the catalytic activity, extensive studies have applied N/F-co-doping to increase its E 1/2 to ∼0.9 V for improving their stability. On this basis, further doping with some elements with electronegativity lower than that of N (2.55) (e.g., B-2.04 and Co-1.88) can endow the material with dual functions. From Table 2, it can be clearly seen that the F-doped noble metal-containing materials usually can make the overpotential lower than 400 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in acidic electrolyte when compared with other elements. However, in alkaline electrolytes, fluorine-containing transition metal-based materials show good performance. They exhibit two characteristics. The one is that F-doping can excite more oxygen vacancies to significantly reduce the overpotential. The other one is that the inclusion of two transition metal elements may further reduce the overpotential. 4.2 1D materials 1D electrocatalytic materials generally have huge mass transfer channels and interconnected conductive networks, which can ensure the continuous progresses of the electrocatalytic convert process. Pyridinic-N, graphitic-N, F–N bonds and C–F bonds in the defect-rich carbon matrix can work together to adjust its electron cloud configuration, and then enriched active sites and reduced interface resistance for high performance ORR. Therefore, Fu et al. and our group both also prepared defect-rich N, F codoped porous carbon nanofibers, which presented excellent electrocatalytic activity that is comparable to commercial Pt/C [9,89]. The highest electronegativity of fluorine also helps to attract electrons from metal atoms, which optimizes the charge distribution of the active site for reducing the reaction activation energy and improving the ORR activity [18]. Leng et al. created FeF2/CoF2 heterojunctions in the carbon nanofibers for enhancing ORR performances [33]. The reasonable pore size in fibers can effectively increase the number of active sites to enhance ORR performance. Ding’s group reported an efficient ORR catalyst of bi-metallic copper fluoride and cobalt fluoride heterojunctions (Fig. 9c), which were uniformly dispersed in the N–F–O triply doped flexible porous carbon nanofibers (Fig. 9d) for providing efficient and stable ORR activities [69]. In addition, fluorine has been shown to be useful for tuning the electronic structure of the metal-nitrogen-carbon active site to further enhance the electrocatalytic stability. Lee et al. designed and synthesized Fe/N/F tri-doped mesoporous carbon nanofibers (Fig. 9e) for effectively improving the electrochemical stability [56]. Due to the enhancement of the electron attraction by F around the FeN4 active sites for ORR, the Fe/N/F tri-doped mesoporous carbon nanofibers exhibited a superior long-term stability of the low negative shift of ∼9 mV than Pt/C catalysts (42 mV). The 1D electrocatalytic materials generally have huge mass transfer channels for oxygen escaping and interconnected conductive networks for electronic conduction, which can ensure abundant exposed active sites, rapid mass transfer and fast gas bubble release. The much charge polarization of C–F bonds by F-doping is beneficial for the generation of a large number of OER active sites. Ali et al. found that fluorine was predominantly attached to CNTs as covalent C–F and semi-ionic C–F moieties, which can enhance OER activity [57]. For F-doped metal compounds, the electrocatalytic performance for OER could be owing to the leaching of inducing defects and metal-oxide formation over the pristine catalyst surface in 1D materials. Zha and co-workers prepared fluorinated FeNi3 alloy in N-doped porous nanofibers (FeNiF/NCF), which exhibited excellent OER catalytic performance due to the increased specific surface area by fluorine dissolution in alkaline solution [90]. The F-doping is beneficial for increasing the electron density near Fermi level, thereby enhancing electron transport capability and reducing the reaction barrier for OER reaction of metal compounds as shown in Fig. 9(f). Due to this electronic structure optimization by fluorine, Chen et al. and Zhong et al. prepared F-doped Co3O4 nanorods and F-doped CoO nanorods for OER, respectively [25,91]. Because the CoO is loaded on the carbon fibers to improve the electronic conductivity, the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 of F-doped CoO (238 mV) was lower than F-doped Co3O4 nanorods (270 mV). Fluorine acting on metal oxyhydroxides leads to high catalytic activity and reduced electrical resistance from the metal oxides. Chen et al. prepared F-doped β-FeOOH nanowires to obtain excellent overpotential for OER (200 mV at 10 mA cm−2) [36]. The F-doping can create oxygen vacancies in metal oxides to increase electron cloud density near the Fermi level to increase electrical conductivity, which was beneficial for high current OER. Xie et al. synthesized F-doped CoMoO4 nanosheet to optimize the electronic configuration for enhancing OER activity, and to reduce the band-gap for strongly increasing the ECSA (141 mF cm−2) for OER activity [18]. More importantly, enabling catalysts to have both ORR and OER is of great significance. S-doping within carbon skeleton can improve the overall electron density at the Fermi level to increase electrical conductivity for boosting oxygen catalytic performance. Wang's group synthesized N, F, S tri-doped carbon nanofibers, which exhibited a positive half-wave potential (∼0.82 V) for ORR and a low overpotential (380 mV at 10 mA cm−2) for OER in alkaline medium [92]. In addition, B atoms cause electron modulation to change the charge distribution and electronic properties and induce defects to facilitate the ORR/OER process. Wang et al. prepared N, F, B tri-doped carbon fibers, which exhibited high catalytic performance for ORR/OER due to the electron modulation of heteroatoms [93]. The F-containing porous carbon 1D catalysts shows the better stability than the non-porous catalysts by comparing the electrocatalyst performance of the 1D for ORR as shown in Table 3 . It is speculated that the pore structure can assist gas diffusion and increase the active surface area to maintain the stability of the ORR process. Therefore, one-dimensional electrocatalytic materials for ORR should pay much attention to the design of the internal pore structures. It can be seen from Table 4 that the fluorinated metallic compounds loaded on carbon nanofibers exhibit lower overpotential (F-CoMoO4− x nanosheet@carbon fibers, 256 mV at 10 mA cm−2) than the F-doped CNTs (280 mV at 10 mA cm−2). In addition, the metal compound nanorods may show better OER performance (F-CoO nanorods, 238 mV at 10 mA cm−2) than the fluorinated metallic compounds loaded on carbon nanofibers. Therefore, the loading of metal compounds can significantly improve the OER performance of F-containing 1D carbon materials. 4.3 2D materials The 2D materials also have been widely researched in oxygen catalysis because of excellent performances such as large surface area, high electric conductivity, regulated structures and easily introducing abundant functional groups [94]. It is particularly notable that F-doping can effectively inhibit the adsorption of oxygen by carbon atoms to prevent the carbon matrix from reacting with oxygen in some cases, thus further improving the electrocatalytic stability. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), Seo et al. found that the edge site of a fluorine-doped 2D graphene nanoribbon (F-GNR) was slightly adsorbed with H2O and was thermodynamically unfavorable with O atoms for more stable host [45]. The Pt/F-GNR exhibits the significantly lower performance degradation 25.0% around 0.6 V compared with 50.2% for Pt/C. The F at edges of the graphene structure can enhance the ORR electrocatalytic activity by electronic optimization. Wen’s group designed stable fluorine-doped graphene (Fig. 10b), which infers that to form more edges could be a good strategy to better enhance the ORR performance of F-doping carbon materials [44]. Fluorine doping can insert the interlayers of 2D graphite to increase the interlayer spacing for exfoliating into graphene, which could expose a large number of active sites to enhance ORR performance. Kakaei et al. and Sofer et al. prepared F-doped graphene via F-doping of graphite materials in fluid, which exhibited a high electronic conductivity and excellent catalytic properties towards the ORR, respectively [10,54]. In N, F co-doped graphene, N-doping produced pyridinic- and pyrrolic-N species for ORR electrocatalytic activity, and the additional F-doping affected the electronic structure and created new active sites for the ORR for further improving electrocatalytic performance. Peera et al., Qiao et al., and Jiang et al. prepared N, F co-doped graphene materials, which exhibited comparable performance of the Pt/C [53,95,96]. Peera et al. prepared N, F co-doped graphene by the exfoliation in the N, F co-doped carbon nanofibers for the low cost and fast preparation [53]. Qiao et al. prepared N, F co-doped graphene by thermal annealing process using a mixture of graphene oxide and ammonium fluoride to obtain numerous slit-shaped pores and high surface area for higher ORR activity [95]. Jiang et al. prepared N, F co-doped graphene via the thermal treatment of graphene oxide/polyaniline composites (GO/ PANI) and NH4F for better stability for ORR [96]. The relatively big atomic radius of S tends to induce more defects on graphene to further improve the higher selectivity of 4e−. Li and co-workers prepared N, F, S tri-doped graphene to cause structural defects and expose more active sites for enhancing the “n” to 3.97 [97]. In addition to the electrocatalytic site generation, the N, F sites on N, F codoped graphene not only can inhibit the oxygen adsorption on graphene matrix for enhancing the electrocatalytic stability, but also can prevent the agglomeration of metal nanoparticles (NPs) via the formation of heteroatom-metal bonds. Sahu’s group prepared the graphene electrocatalysts separately modified by Pt-NPs and Fe/Co-NPs, which showed excellent ORR activity and outstanding stability [49,50]. Recently, F-doping on graphene materials was found to be able to weaken CN bonds to drive nitrogen atoms to bond with metal nanoparticles. Chang and coworkers found that the F-doping could create a more N-rich Pd surface to inhibit the Pd migration and adjust the environment around the Pd, which improved both activity (E 1/2 = 0.91 V vs. RHE) and durability for ORR [26]. Due to the electronic regulation by fluorine, the N, F co-doped graphene also displays improved OER performance. Yue et al. and Sim et al. found that N, F co-doping on graphene materials was favor for reducing the activation energy of OER to enhance the OER performance [58,98]. As is well known, the F− ions can effectively catch electrons from their neighboring metal atoms and optimize the adsorption properties into layered oxyhydroxides intermediates leading to more outstanding OER activity than F-doped Graphene. Due to the electronic optimization of F-doping, Chen et al. prepared F-doped Ni3(OH)4 nanosheets, which enabled a lower overpotential (280 mV) at 10 mA cm−2 than the pure Ni3(OH)4 (340 mV) for OER [99]. Furthermore, due to the occupying of F-ions in O-ions, the lattice order would be regulated to reduce charge imbalance for enhancing the OER kinetics. Therefore, Han’s group found that the existence of F-dopants significantly changed the intrinsic structure of the pristine Ni(OH)2 to reduce the overpotential (280 mV at 50 mA cm−2) in OER (Fig. 10c) [37]. In some cases, the fluorination process directly causes the metal particles to form a layered structure, which could substantially improve surface wettability and gas-bubble-releasing behavior for OER as shown in Fig. 10(d). Xu et al. found that fluorination process enables the formation of ultrathin NiFeO x F y nanosheets for excellent OER performance [62]. For further enhancing OER kinetics, the F-doping and O-vacancies can synergistically break the water molecule to OH* and H* to strongly reduce the energy barrier in some cases. Li’s group designed and prepared F-doped Co3O4 nanoarrays with O-vacancies on graphene as shown in Fig. 10(e), which exhibited very low overpotential (77 and 192 mV at 10 and 100 mA cm−2) for OER due to the synergy of F-doping and O-vacancies [34]. The OER/ORR dual function makes the zinc-air battery rechargeable. Zhang and Dai prepared N/P/F tri-doped graphene to achieve OER and ORR electrocatalysis [100]. The polarization of the graphene matrix by N/P/F with different electronegativity resulted in a large variety of active sites for the improved oxygen catalysis performance. As shown in Table 5 , the F-containing noble metal-based 2D catalysts exhibit significantly higher ORR catalytic activity. For non-noble metal catalysts, the ORR activity of N/F co-doped graphene is better than that of F-doped graphene alone. The F-containing porous graphene material also exhibits better ORR activity than the general F-containing graphene. The incorporation of transition metals also further enhances the ORR catalytic activity of F-containing graphene in acidic electrolytes. It can be seen from Table 6 that the 2D F-containing transition metal oxides and hydroxides all exhibit higher OER catalytic ability than these graphene materials. In particular, the prepared F-Co3O4 nanosheets exhibit the overpotential of 192 mV at 100 mA cm−2 and the activity retention of 98% at 120 h. All in all, current researches on 2D F-containing transition metal nanosheets for OER have focused on magnetic elements. The effect of fluorine on nonmagnetic elemental nanosheets remains to need to be further explored. 4.4 3D materials The 3D materials for oxygen electrocatalysis include carbon skeleton materials driven by organic framework materials and nickel foam matrix materials, etc. They possess self-supporting frameworks to ensure effective mass transport and fast electronic conduction for oxygen catalysis. Organic framework materials are precursors that can effectively design catalyst structures to obtain the appropriate chemical composition for efficient ORR. Fluorine can tune the charge state of the metalNC active site for lower ORR activation energy. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), Diao et al. prepared tri-(Fe/N/F)-doped porous carbons derived by ZIF-8, which had the F enhanced FeN4 active sites for excellent ORR process (E 1/2 = 0.872 V vs. RHE) in alkaline electrolyte [101]. Due to the surface activation on ZIFs of perfluorotetradecanoic-acid (PFTA, a surfactants), Tao et al. prepared tri-(Fe/N/F)-doped porous carbons with large surface area (1085 m2 g−1) for low H2O2 production (<3%) for ORR in acid electrolyte [48]. Fluorination of MOF-derived materials generally preserves their original morphology and generates metal fluorides. The metal fluorides can form metal hydroxides by surface hydration. Due to the charge-regulating effect of F on metal hydroxides, the transition state structure of OER is optimized to reduce the reaction activation energy to enhance the OER catalytic performance. Gu et al. obtained CoF2 on N-doped carbons derived by ZIF-67 to yield a low overpotential of 294 mV for OER (Fig. 11b) [102]. Doping CoF2 with a certain amount of iron will optimize the structure of the OER transition state of the metal hydroxide generated by surface hydration to enhance the OER catalytic activity. Li and co-workers prepared MOF derived Co2FeF6 microcubes, to reduce the OER overpotential (260 mV at 10 mA cm−2) [35]. The alloy can offer high conductance, and the electronic modulation of fluorine on the surface metal hydration products would accelerate the kinetics of OER. Due to the high electrical conductivity provided by the alloy and the high catalytic activity brought by fluorine, Li et al. demonstrated FeNi MOF derived carbon confined FeNi/FeF2 for further reducing OER overpotential (250 mV at 10 mA cm−2) [106]. Fluorination of Prussian-blue-analogue (PBA) could derive a series of novel and robust catalysts for OER. Pei and coworkers prepared hollow KCoFeF6 nano cubes to offer a low overpotential of 250 mV (10 mA cm−2) for OER as shown in Fig. 11(c) [103]. By combining the design flexibility of MOFs and the robust of PBAs, Gu’s group prepared ZIF-67@CoFe-PBA on fluorinate lower overpotential of 243 mV (10 mA cm−2) without IR correction for OER [107]. Metal foams possess excellent electrical conductivity, self-supporting ability and three-dimensional through-hole structure, which could maintain high electrocatalytic activity process. The fluorination on metal-foams would result in a large number of structural distortions and various defects for improving the OER catalysis. Fan and co-workers obtained the Fe2O3/FeF2 heterostructure on Fe-foam to cause a large number of structural distortions and various defects for efficient OER catalysis and a low overpotential (260 mV at 10 mA cm−2) [61]. The F-doped Ni-foam would occur partial dissolution with the migration of F-ions in alkaline solution, which could form F-doped layered double metal hydroxides (LDHs) with another metal on the surface of metal-foam. Due to the electronic regulation by fluorine, the obtained F-doped LDHs could enhance the catalytic activity for OER. Tong et al. prepared F-doped NiAl-LDHs on Ni-foam to reduce the overpotential (250 mV at 10 mA cm−2) [108]. Transition metals have partially free d-orbitals, which may reduce the charge imbalance in the adsorbed state of the material and further reduce the activation energy of the reaction. Ma et al. prepared F-doped NiFe-OOH, which had a lower OER overpotential (190 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and higher intrinsic catalytic activity than the fluorine free NiFe-OOH (Fig. 11e) [104]. OER electrocatalytic activity could be further enhanced due to the good electrical conductivity of metal sulfides and the co-optimization of OER transition states by sulfur-fluorine. Therefore, Xu and coworkers prepared F-doped Ni3S2 on the Ni foam for excellent overpotential 239 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in OER as shown in Fig. 11(f) [105]. In some cases, the obtained NH4F can promote anisotropic growth for generating elongated grains on nickel foam to optimize gas escape channels for high current OER. Due to the anisotropic growth by NH4F, Hao et al. and Song et al. separately prepared CoP nanorods and F-doped Ni3S2 nanorods on Ni-foam, respectively [59,109]. The CoP achieved a low overpotential of 230 mV at 20 mA cm−2 due to the optimization of the energy of transition state by fluorine and the high conductivity of Ni-foam [109]. For the F-doped Ni3S2 nanorods, they also realized a low overpotential of 360 mV at 100 mA cm−2 due to the enhanced electronic conductivity of Ni3S2 and the nanorods on 3D porous structure for shorter O2 diffusion [59]. Notably, due to the high conductivity of the alloy, Zhou et al. prepared F-doped NiMoO4 nanorods on MoNi foam (F-NiMoO4@MNF) to reduce the high current OER overpotential (188 mV at 50 mA cm−2) based on the synergistic effect of the migration of F species and effective penetration of the electrolyte [60]. Rechargeable metal-air batteries require bifunctional electrocatalysts. The F doping with graphitic and pyridinic N could trigger the active paramagnetic centers to reduce the energy barrier for OER and ORR. Benefitting from this feature, Sun et al. prepared N/F codoped porous carbon materials derived by COFs, which exhibited high electrocatalytic activities for both ORR and OER and was successfully used in zinc-air batteries as the air cathode electrocatalyst (Fig. 11d) [11]. The polarization of the carbon hosts by different electronegativity elements could cause a large variety of active sites for ORR and OER catalysis. Zheng and co-workers constructed N/P/F tri-doped porous carbon through ultrasound-triggered piperazine-containing covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs), and it could use for high performance rechargeable Zn-air batteries [110]. It can be seen from Table 7 that Fe doping may enhance their ORR catalytic activity in organic self-assembled materials. Some materials other than MOFs, such as COFs and CTFs, exhibit the huge potential for ORR/OER dual catalytic functions. As shown in Table 8 , the F-containing PBAs exhibits slightly better OER performance than the F-containing MOF derivatives. The prepared materials based on the nickel foam framework exhibit significantly better OER activity (F-doped NiFe-OOH@Ni-foam, 190 mV at 10 mA cm−2). Bimetallic foam matrices seem to show more excellent OER catalytic ability than single metallic foam matrices (F-NiMoO4 nanorods@MoNi-foam, 188 mV at 50 mA cm−2). If the obtained F-doped Ni3S2 nanorods are grown on the surface of nickel foam, a higher catalytic current density can be obtained (F-Ni3S2 nanorods@Ni-foam, 360 mV at 100 mA cm−2). Compared with the fluorine free material, the more excellent catalytic performance is due to the higher electron density near the Fermi level of the metal sulfides and the improved oxygen escape capability of the nanorods. In summary, the main purpose of material structure design is to increase the area of the three-phase interface (gas, liquid and solid) to expose more active sites. Therefore, fluorination process is a very important method to increase the specific surface area of materials. On the one hand, fluorine etching of carbon materials can effectively enlarge the graphite interlayer spacing and form burrs at the edges to increase the surface area. On the other hand, fluorination of metal-based materials also can form a platelet-like structure to increase the surface area. The structural design of fluorination has been extensively studied. Materials with different dimensions (0D, 1D, 2D and 3D) have their own unique advantages. The 0D materials have adjustable pore size distribution, designable shells, unique surface properties and ultra-high specific surface to produce plenty of active sites. And 1D electrocatalytic materials generally have huge mass transfer channels and interconnected conductive networks, which can ensure the continuous progresses of the electrocatalytic convert process. The 2D materials have large surface area, high electric conductivity, regulated structures and easily introducing abundant functional groups. The 3D materials possess self-supporting frameworks to ensure effective mass transport and fast electronic conduction for oxygen catalysis. A rational combination of material properties and morphological features can greatly improve the electrochemical performance of oxygen electrocatalysts. 5 Summary and outlook The high electronegativity (4.0) of fluorine leads to the excellent properties of fluorine-containing oxygen catalysts. The fluorine can provide versatile strategies to produce efficient electrocatalysts with porous characteristics, high catalytic activity and stable chemical properties. According to the preparation process of fluorine-containing oxygen catalyst, it can mainly be divided into adsorption, thermal doping, co-crystallization and self-assembly. These modification methods can endow various materials with many properties to enhance the electrocatalytic performances. For instance, increased stability, more exposed active sites, optimized atomic arrangement, enhanced conductivity, improved hydrophilic, raised catalytic activity and so on. Most of the existing studies mainly focus on the thermal doping of fluorine in materials or the inclusion of fluorine in carbonization processes. Therefore, choosing the appropriate fluorination method for a variety of targets is a major challenge in achieving high fluorine content in various materials. Traditional fluorination processes have some many drawbacks such as slow preparation rates, low fluorine content and so on, making a lot of sense to develop and innovate the fluorination process in these aspects. In addition to the preparation methods, the researches of catalysts are inseparable from the action mechanism exploration. For carbon materials, the following mechanisms can further improve the ORR performance: (a) The fluorine enrichment at the edge of the carbon material also can prevent the corrosion of the carbon materials and improve the ORR catalytic stability by reducing the binding energy between oxygen and the F-substituted edge of materials. (b) The fluorine in the graphite material can decrease the interlayer binding energy to enlarge the layer distance, which greatly increases the specific surface area and exposes active sites for efficient ORR catalysis. (c) The fluorine in carbon materials can produce synergistic effects with other heteroatoms to enhance ORR performance. Distinguishing true active sites still is challenging because of the wide variety of possible active sites in carbon materials. The current researches generally perform transition state simulations to find possible active sites by applying density functional theory. However, few studies characterize the catalytic in situ process through the transition state to verify the corresponding simulation results. Therefore, there is still a need to develop some novel in situ characterization approaches to understand their more fundamental action mechanisms. Insufficient connection between theoretical models and experiments is one of the challenges in the current further mechanism exploration of F-containing oxygen electrocatalysts. Fluorine-containing metal-based materials also occupy an important position. The following mechanisms can further improve the performance of metal-based catalysts. (a) The fluorine in the metal compound can be dissolved out in the reaction system, which can generate a porous structure and can be replaced by water and oxygen at the edge to generate a highly OER active oxyhydroxides. (b) The doping of fluorine in metal compounds may transform the crystal structure, thereby enhancing the OER intrinsic catalytic activity. (c) The F-doping in metal oxides can induce oxygen vacancies, which synergistically adjust the internal charge structure and enhance the electrical conductivity for improving the electrocatalytic performances. When compared with carbon materials, the metal-based materials perform better in catalytic OER. Generally speaking, the energy difference is small between general metal hydroxides and metal oxyhydroxides. Therefore, developing high-performance metal-based ORR catalysts still is a rather challenge. If a material with a large energy difference between oxyhydroxide and hydroxide can be developed, it is expected to prepare high-performance metal-based ORR catalysts. All of these merits would be a very interesting and important research direction. The morphology of the materials is also critical for oxygen catalytic activity. The main purpose of material structure design is to increase the area of the three-phase interface (gas, liquid and solid) to expose more active sites. Therefore, fluorination process is a very important method to increase the specific surface area of materials. On the one hand, fluorine etching of carbon materials also can effectively enlarge the graphite interlayer spacing and form burrs at the edges to increase the surface area. On the other hand, fluorination of metal-based materials can sometimes form a platelet-like structure to increase the surface area. Various materials of different dimensions have their own unique advantages. The 0D materials have adjustable pore size distribution, designable shells, unique surface properties and ultra-high specific surface to produce plenty of active sites. The 1D electrocatalytic materials generally have huge mass transfer channels and interconnected conductive networks, which can ensure the continuous progresses of the electrocatalytic convert process. The 2D materials have large surface area, excellent electric conductivity, regulated structures and easily introducing abundant functional groups. The 3D materials possess self-supporting frameworks to ensure effective mass transport and fast electronic conduction for oxygen catalysis. Designing rational morphologies for various materials can greatly improve the electrochemical performance of oxygen electrocatalysts. It is worth mentioning that, in acidic electrolytes, some F-containing oxygen catalysts can only exhibit oxygen electrocatalytic performance equivalent to that in alkaline conditions (E 1/2> 0.85 V for ORR or overpotential <300 mV at 10 mA cm−2 for OER). For example, the prepared Pt/F co-doped graphene for ORR and F-doped IrO2 for OER were designed and prepared for oxygen electrocatalysts. And some single-atom catalysts with axial fluorine atom coordination also can be developed to effectively improve their ORR catalytic performance [111]. Correspondingly, some fluorine-containing metal compound materials (e.g., AlF3) that are poorly soluble in acidic electrolytes should also be investigated for OER. In addition, some adding corresponding metal salts into the electrolyte to inhibit the dissolution of F-containing metal compounds may enhance its stability in acidic electrolytes. At present, as shown in Fig. 12 , fluorine-containing catalysts for oxygen electrocatalysis have great potential to be explored in the novel catalytic pathway for fast kinetics, the advanced research methods for mechanism exploration, the multi-functional materials for practical application and the field-assisted effects for effective oxygen electrocatalytic reaction. The novel catalytic pathway can help to expand possible mechanisms of action and increases the options for novel catalyst designs to obtain fast kinetics. For ORR, the C8F (fluorine is assigned to every 8 carbon atoms) graphene can moderately activate the O2 molecule, which prompts the O2 to become double *O to promote the subsequent ORR through novel and more efficient associative pathways of four electrons [46]. For OER, the F-doping and O-vacancies also can synergistically break the energy barrier limit of water dissociation step to be *H and *OH for efficient water splitting [34]. However, the study of OER/ORR bifunctional electrocatalysts only developed to combine efficient ORR catalytic components and high-performance OER catalytic components to achieve bifunctional catalysis. The development of novel catalytic pathways for F-doped bifunctional electrocatalysts for OER/ORR and in-depth mechanistic investigations are of great research value. Advanced research methods could help us to accurately understand the specific mechanism in materials. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy is a method for studying materials that have unpaired electrons, which is particularly useful for studying metal complexes and oxygen vacancies [112]. In addition, X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) techniques, e.g., extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES), are widely applied for determining the local geometric and/or electronic structure of matter [113]. More importantly, in the research, the path analysis of electronic density of states (DOS) and Gibbs free energy based on first-principles calculations of DFT should be widely used to deeply analyze the mechanism of action of each component in materials [114]. Especially, due to the rapid development of integrated circuit technology, high-throughput computational screening based on machine learning technology has become within reach [115], which the method can rapidly screen out reasonable materials with desired properties to greatly speed up the development of new catalysts [116]. The construction of a rational model can lead the research direction for fluorine-containing oxygen electrocatalysts. Compared with other materials, the model of fluorine-containing materials may have better robustness theoretically due to the strongest electronegativity and stable valence state of fluorine. Therefore, it is urgent to develop a rational model for fluorine-containing materials to promote and lead the researches on their oxygen electrocatalytic properties. The theoretical researches by advanced methods of measurement and simulation have become indispensable in electrocatalyst researches. The multi-functionalization of materials can greatly enhance their application of oxygen electrocatalysis, which is beneficial to future industrial production. The ORR-OER bifunctional electrocatalyst can simultaneously meet the needs of cathodes for metal-air batteries in charge–discharge cycles [11]. The ORR-MOR (MOR, small molecule oxidation reaction) bifunctional electrocatalyst can meet the needs of positive and negative electrodes of vehicle fuel cells at the same time [26]. And the OER-HER (HER, hydrogen evolution reaction) bifunctional electrocatalyst can meet the needs of positive and negative electrodes of water splitting [34]. The multi-functionalities of electrocatalysts are considered one of the future development directions. Field-assisted methods can improve oxygen catalytic reaction kinetics from many perspectives [117]. At present, a few studies found that light can modulate the energy states of charged carriers in the F-contain catalysts for enhancing the OER performance [65]. Apart from that, other field-assisted methods can also enhance oxygen catalysis in theory but have been less studied in F-containing materials. For example, a gate electric field can simultaneously adjust the distribution of charged species and the electrical conductivity of catalysts at the catalyst-electrolyte heterogenous interface [118]. An alternating magnetic field can change the spin states of reaction intermediates to enhance the catalytic activity [119]. A periodic strain can modulate d-band centers of active sites for better catalytic paths [120]. Through reasonable designs for various catalysts and catalytic systems, the synergy of field effects holds broad prospects for improved energy utilization. In the review, we systematically summarize and detailed review the controllable preparation methods based on fluorine-containing materials for oxygen electrocatalysis. And the effects of materials are classified based on their effective working mechanisms of fluorine-containing materials, and the corresponding mechanisms and expected effects also are summarized. More importantly, the prospects and possible future researching direction of F-containing oxygen electrocatalysts are presented in this review. All in all, the review is considered valuable and helpful in exploring the novel design and mechanism analysis of advanced fluorine-containing electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Non-renewable fossil fuels have led to serious problems such as global warming, environmental pollution, etc. Oxygen electrocatalysis including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays a central role in clean energy conversion, enabling a number of sustainable processes for future air battery technologies. Fluorine, as the most electronegative element (4.0) not only can induce more efficient regulation for the electronic structure, but also can bring more abundant defects and other novel effects in materials selection and preparation for favorable catalysis with respect to the other non-metal elements. However, an individual and comprehensive overview of fluorine-containing functional materials for oxygen electrocatalysis field is still blank. Therefore, it is very meaningful to review the recent progresses of fluorine-containing oxygen electrocatalysts. In this review, we first systematically summarize the controllable preparation methods and their possible development directions based on fluorine-containing materials from four preparation methods. Due to the strong electron-withdrawing properties of fluorine, its control of the electronic structure can effectively enhance the oxygen electrocatalytic activity of the materials. In addition, the catalytic enhancement effect of fluorine on carbon-based materials also includes the prevent oxidation and the layer peeling, and realizes the precise atomic control. And the catalytic improvement mechanism of fluorine containing metal-based compounds also includes the hydration of metal site, the crystal transformation, and the oxygen vacancy induction. Then, based on their various dimensions (0D–3D), we also have summarized the advantages of different morphologies on oxygen electrocatalytic performances. Finally, the prospects and possible future researching direction of F-containing oxygen electrocatalysts are presented (e.g., novel pathways, advanced methods for measurement and simulation, field assistance and multi-functions). The review is considered valuable and helpful in exploring the novel designs and mechanism analyses of advanced fluorine-containing electrocatalysts.
